unnormalised: Okay, here's a Quora Post on "Urban Gym Culture" for the "Lifestyle & Wellness" category, keeping your specifications in mind:
normalised: Okay, here's the normalized version of the Quora post based on your rules:

unnormalised: **Urban Gym Culture: Is it really changing us?**
normalised: **Urban Gym Culture: Is it really changing us?**

unnormalised: So, I've been hitting the gyms in Bangalore for, well, almost 5 years now, and I gotta say, the "urban gym culture" is a real thing. It’s definitely more than just lifting weights these days.
normalised: So, I have been hitting the gyms in Bangalore for, well, almost five years now, and I have got to say, the "urban gym culture" is a real thing. It’s definitely more than just lifting weights these days.

unnormalised: Back in the day, it was mostly bodybuilders and uncles trying to stay in shape. Now, you see everyone - college kids from Christ University, young professionals from IT companies, even auntyjis getting their Zumba on. The whole vibe is different. It's less about pure strength and more about overall wellness – yoga, HIIT, even group dance fitness classes.
normalised: Back in the day, it was mostly bodybuilders and uncles trying to stay in shape. Now, you see everyone - college kids from Christ University, young professionals from I T companies, even auntyjis getting their Zumba on. The whole vibe is different. It's less about pure strength and more about overall wellness – yoga, H I I T, even group dance fitness classes.

unnormalised: But is it all positive? On one hand, awareness about fitness is amazing. We’re more conscious about our diets, track our steps, and even compare protein intake! Gyms are popping up everywhere - Gold's Gym, Cult.fit, local ones in every other 200 sq ft space promising you a six-pack in 3 months. That accessibility is key.
normalised: But is it all positive? On one hand, awareness about fitness is amazing. We’re more conscious about our diets, track our steps, and even compare protein intake! Gyms are popping up everywhere - Gold's Gym, Cult dot fit, local ones in every other two hundred square feet space promising you a six-pack in three months. That accessibility is key.

unnormalised: On the other hand, sometimes it feels…performative. People are more focused on getting the perfect gym selfie for Instagram than actually pushing themselves. And let’s be real, some of these fancy protein shakes cost more than my monthly rent! Dr. Sharma from my apartment complex says the pressure to look "gym-fit" can be stressful, especially for youngsters.
normalised: On the other hand, sometimes it feels…performative. People are more focused on getting the perfect gym selfie for Instagram than actually pushing themselves. And let’s be real, some of these fancy protein shakes cost more than my monthly rent! Doctor Sharma from my apartment complex says the pressure to look "gym-fit" can be stressful, especially for youngsters.

unnormalised: What do you guys think? Has the urban gym culture improved our lives, or has it added another layer of pressure? What are your experiences in places like Delhi, Mumbai, or even smaller cities like Lucknow? Are the Rs. 20,000+ yearly memberships really worth it? Let's discuss!
normalised: What do you guys think? Has the urban gym culture improved our lives, or has it added another layer of pressure? What are your experiences in places like Delhi, Mumbai, or even smaller cities like Lucknow? Are the rupee twenty thousand plus yearly memberships really worth it? Let's discuss!
